field.name: Commercial Real Estate
field.description: Commercial real estate encompasses properties used for business purposes, including office buildings, retail spaces, industrial facilities, multifamily housing, and hospitality properties. This field covers investment, development, leasing, and management of income-producing properties.

problems.title: Commercial Real Estate Debt Maturity Wall and Refinancing Crisis
problems.description: The commercial real estate industry faces an unprecedented debt maturity crisis, with approximately $1.8 trillion in commercial loans scheduled to mature by 2026. Property owners who borrowed when interest rates were near historic lows now face refinancing at significantly higher rates, creating severe financial strain. In 2025 alone, $957 billion in commercial mortgages matured, with another $539 billion due in 2026—both figures well above the 20-year average of $350 billion annually. Many lenders are extending loans (known as 'extend and pretend') while awaiting market improvements, but this approach creates regulatory concerns and strains capital reserves. The crisis is particularly acute for office properties, where declining valuations have left many borrowers underwater. Property owners must either inject substantial additional equity, accept unfavorable terms, or face potential default. This debt wall threatens to trigger widespread distressed sales, further depressing property values and creating systemic risk in the financial sector.
problems.summary: Nearly $1.8 trillion in commercial real estate loans are maturing in 2025-2026, forcing property owners to refinance at significantly higher interest rates, threatening widespread defaults and market instability.

barriers: Limited refinancing options for distressed properties

neglectedness.fundingLevel: High attention but limited intervention tools

rootCauses.description: Aggressive Federal Reserve rate hikes from near-zero to 5.25-5.50% between 2022-2023
Property owners leveraged at historically low rates during 2020-2021
Declining property values especially in office sector reducing loan-to-value ratios
Banks tightening lending standards amid regulatory scrutiny

consequences.description: Increased loan defaults and foreclosures across commercial real estate
Regional bank stress due to concentrated CRE exposure
Reduced new development and construction activity
Forced sales depressing property valuations across markets

limitations: Delays rather than solves underlying problem

limitations: May not be economically justified for distressed assets

limitations: Fund capacity limited relative to market size

problems.title: Office Space Oversupply and Record Vacancy Rates Post-Pandemic
problems.description: The commercial office market is experiencing an unprecedented oversupply crisis, with national vacancy rates reaching a three-decade high of 20.4% in late 2024. The shift to remote and hybrid work accelerated by the COVID-19 pandemic has fundamentally altered demand for office space, with companies downsizing footprints by 30-50% on average. While Class A buildings with modern amenities maintain competitive occupancy, Class B and particularly Class C buildings face structural obsolescence, with some markets seeing vacancy rates exceeding 30%. This oversupply is driving significant rent declines, with effective rents down 15-25% in many markets. Property values have plummeted, with some office buildings selling for 50-90% below their peak valuations. The crisis is particularly severe in tech-centric markets like San Francisco (37% vacancy), though virtually every major metro is affected. The oversupply represents a fundamental market correction that will take years to resolve through demolition, conversion, or eventual demand recovery.
problems.summary: Office vacancy rates have reached a 30-year high of 20.4% nationally, driven by permanent shifts to hybrid work, causing severe rent declines and property devaluation especially for older Class B and C buildings.

barriers: Long lease terms on existing space

neglectedness.fundingLevel: High attention from industry and policymakers

rootCauses.description: COVID-19 pandemic accelerating adoption of remote and hybrid work
Technology enabling productive remote collaboration

Over-building during 2010s expansion cycle

Reduced property tax revenues for municipalities dependent on commercial real estate
Decline of downtown urban cores affecting retail, restaurants, and transit
Stranded assets and potential demolition of obsolete buildings

problems.title: Escalating Commercial Property Insurance Costs Due to Climate Risk
problems.description: Commercial property owners face rapidly escalating insurance costs driven by climate change and increasing natural disaster frequency. Property insurance premiums have increased up to 300% from just a few years ago in high-risk markets, with national commercial property insurance seeing 7.6% annual growth rates since 2017 and some markets experiencing year-over-year increases exceeding 17%. This surge is particularly severe for properties in areas prone to hurricanes, wildfires, floods, and severe storms. In some regions, insurers are withdrawing coverage entirely, leaving property owners unable to secure required insurance for lending compliance. The rising costs directly impact property valuations, as higher operating expenses reduce net operating income and thus asset values. Many owners face difficult choices between accepting reduced coverage, dramatically higher deductibles, or selling properties in high-risk areas. The insurance crisis is reshaping investment decisions, with capital flowing away from climate-vulnerable markets and creating stranded asset risk for existing portfolios.
problems.summary: Commercial property insurance premiums have increased up to 3x in recent years due to climate-related claims, with some markets seeing 17%+ annual increases, threatening property economics and investment viability.

rootCauses.description: Increasing frequency and severity of natural disasters due to climate change
Historic underpricing of climate risk in insurance markets
Concentration of development in high-risk coastal and wildfire-prone areas
Reinsurance market repricing climate exposure globally

consequences.description: Reduced property values as higher insurance costs decrease NOI
Lending challenges as insurers withdraw from high-risk markets
Investment capital flight from climate-vulnerable regions
Potential for uninsured losses leaving property owners exposed

problems.title: Digital Transformation Barriers and Legacy Technology in Commercial Real Estate
problems.description: The commercial real estate industry struggles with digital transformation, hindered by fragmented legacy systems, data silos, and resistance to technological change. Despite the availability of over 367 different proptech tools, only 14% of CRE organizations have well-structured data management systems, and 61% continue to rely on legacy systems for core operations. AI implementation presents particular challenges, with 27% of organizations experiencing technical issues, lack of expertise, or resistance to change. Data fragmentation is severe: building systems for lighting, HVAC, access control, and energy management often operate independently without integration, making comprehensive analytics nearly impossible. The industry's transaction-oriented culture, combined with fragmented ownership structures and long asset holding periods, creates weak incentives for technology investment. Small and mid-sized property owners lack resources for digital transformation while larger players struggle with integration across diverse portfolios. This technological lag reduces operational efficiency, limits data-driven decision-making, and creates competitive disadvantages against more digitally sophisticated market participants.
problems.summary: Only 14% of commercial real estate organizations have well-structured data systems, with 61% relying on legacy technology, creating operational inefficiencies and barriers to AI adoption and data-driven management.

rootCauses.description: Fragmented ownership structure with thousands of independent operators
Long asset holding periods reducing urgency for technology upgrades
Building systems designed as independent silos without integration standards
Industry culture prioritizing relationships over technological efficiency

consequences.description: Inefficient operations increasing operating costs by 15-25%
Poor data quality hindering investment decision-making
Inability to meet tenant expectations for digital services
Challenges meeting ESG reporting requirements due to data gaps

problems.title: ESG Compliance and Sustainability Reporting Complexity in Commercial Real Estate
problems.description: Commercial real estate faces mounting challenges complying with evolving ESG requirements and sustainability regulations. Buildings account for approximately 39% of global carbon emissions, making the sector a primary focus of climate policy. Property owners must navigate rapidly proliferating building performance standards across jurisdictions—many requiring energy use reductions, carbon emissions caps, and penalties for non-compliance. Scope 3 emissions reporting presents particular difficulties, as these indirect emissions account for up to 90% of a company's total but require collecting data from tenants who may be unwilling or unable to share consumption information. The lack of standardized ESG metrics creates reporting confusion, with different frameworks (GRESB, CDP, TCFD, SFDR) requiring varied data and methodologies. Only 15% of global real estate assets are currently on track to meet Paris Agreement 1.5°C targets. Meanwhile, fear of 'greenwashing' accusations has led to 'greenhushing'—companies avoiding disclosure of sustainability initiatives to reduce litigation risk—creating a counterproductive chilling effect on transparency.
problems.summary: Commercial real estate owners struggle with complex ESG regulations across jurisdictions, Scope 3 emissions data collection challenges, and inconsistent reporting frameworks while facing the reality that only 15% of assets meet climate targets.

rootCauses.description: Buildings contributing 39% of global carbon emissions requiring urgent decarbonization
Proliferation of local, state, and national building performance standards
Split incentives between landlords and tenants for energy improvements
Lack of global consensus on ESG metrics and methodologies

consequences.description: Compliance costs and potential penalties for building performance failures
Stranded asset risk for buildings that cannot meet future emissions requirements
Restricted access to capital as ESG-focused investors dominate markets
'Green premium' creating competitive disadvantages for non-compliant buildings

problems.title: Commercial Property Valuation Uncertainty and Public-Private Market Disconnect
problems.description: Commercial real estate faces a valuation crisis characterized by significant uncertainty and a troubling disconnect between public and private market pricing. Publicly traded REITs have experienced sharp declines reflecting higher cap rates and lower valuations, while private market appraisals have been slower to adjust, creating confusion about true asset values. Some office buildings have sold for 50-90% below their peak valuations, yet many private portfolios have not yet recognized comparable write-downs. This disconnect creates several problems: investors cannot accurately assess portfolio values, lenders struggle to determine appropriate loan-to-value ratios, and transaction activity is suppressed as buyers and sellers cannot agree on pricing. Rising cap rates driven by higher interest rates are mechanically reducing values even for well-performing assets. Portfolio risk has moved to the forefront for investors, lenders, auditors, and occupiers as traditional cap rate compression that drove historical returns is no longer viable. The uncertainty is particularly acute for office assets, but affects all property types to varying degrees.
problems.summary: Commercial real estate faces severe valuation uncertainty with public and private markets showing significant pricing disconnects, some office assets selling 50-90% below peaks while private appraisals lag reality.

barriers: Limited transaction data in current market
Complexity of adjusting for unique property characteristics

rootCauses.description: Rapid interest rate increases changing discount rates used in valuations
Private market appraisals lagging public market price discovery
Reduced transaction volume limiting comparable sales data
Fundamental uncertainty about future demand for certain property types

consequences.description: Transaction paralysis as buyers and sellers cannot agree on pricing
Inaccurate portfolio reporting for institutional investors and pension funds
Lending uncertainty as banks struggle to assess collateral values
Potential mark-to-market shocks when private valuations eventually adjust

problems.title: Office-to-Residential Conversion Barriers and Adaptive Reuse Challenges
problems.description: Despite high office vacancy rates and severe housing shortages in many markets, converting office buildings to residential use faces significant barriers that limit widespread adoption. Only approximately 1.1% of vacant office space is suitable for conversion, primarily due to building design constraints—modern office towers built after 1980 feature wide floor plates (often 40,000+ square feet) that cannot provide adequate natural light and ventilation for residential units under building codes. Conversion costs range from $100 to $500+ per square foot, often exceeding new construction costs, while financing remains challenging due to project complexity and lender unfamiliarity. Zoning restrictions prevent conversions in many office-zoned districts without lengthy reentitlement processes. Environmental remediation, structural modifications, and code compliance (including requirements for operable windows and residential egress) add further complexity. The conversion timeline of 8-16 months minimum, combined with economic uncertainty, makes projects difficult to underwrite. While some cities are implementing incentive programs and streamlined approvals, the fundamental physical constraints of most office buildings severely limit conversion potential as a solution to either the office glut or housing shortage.
problems.summary: Office-to-residential conversions face severe constraints: only 1.1% of office space is suitable, costs reach $100-500+/sqft, zoning barriers persist, and building designs prevent adequate light and ventilation for housing.

neglectedness.fundingLevel: Growing policy attention but limited private investment

rootCauses.description: Post-1980 office buildings designed with deep floor plates unsuitable for residential
Building codes requiring natural light and ventilation in every habitable room
Single-use zoning preventing residential development in office districts
Limited financing products for complex conversion projects

consequences.description: Obsolete office buildings remaining vacant rather than being repurposed

Downtown areas remaining underutilized and economically depressed
Eventual demolition of buildings with remaining structural life

problems.title: Political and Economic Policy Uncertainty Impacting Commercial Real Estate Investment
problems.description: Commercial real estate investment faces significant headwinds from elevated political and economic policy uncertainty. Political uncertainty topped the list of concerns in industry surveys, as potential changes in regulation, immigration policy, trade tariffs, and fiscal policy create an unpredictable operating environment. The Federal Reserve's interest rate policy remains a key uncertainty, with rates held steady in 2025 despite earlier expectations of cuts, keeping borrowing costs elevated and suppressing transaction activity. Immigration policy changes threaten to impact construction labor availability and demographic trends driving housing demand. Potential regulatory shifts around environmental rules, rent control, and development approvals add to planning challenges. This uncertainty paralyzes decision-making, as investors delay acquisitions pending clarity on policy direction, developers struggle to underwrite projects with unpredictable cost and revenue assumptions, and lenders tighten standards to account for unknown risks. The resulting reduced transaction volume creates a self-reinforcing cycle of illiquidity and price discovery challenges.
problems.summary: Political and economic policy uncertainty is suppressing commercial real estate investment activity, with unpredictable interest rates, regulatory changes, and immigration policy creating planning paralysis.

barriers: Limited ability to predict policy outcomes

neglectedness.fundingLevel: High attention but limited interventions available

rootCauses.description: Elevated inflation requiring restrictive monetary policy
Political polarization creating policy volatility between administrations
Global geopolitical tensions affecting supply chains and capital flows
State and local policy divergence on housing, environment, and development

consequences.description: Reduced transaction volume as investors await policy clarity
Delayed development starts due to uncertain cost and approval environments
Wider bid-ask spreads as buyers and sellers disagree on risk pricing
Capital allocation shifts to lower-uncertainty markets and asset classes

problems.title: Demographic Shifts Impacting Commercial Real Estate Demand Fundamentals
problems.description: Commercial real estate faces structural demand challenges from significant demographic shifts in population growth, migration patterns, and household formation. Overall U.S. population growth is slowing, with immigration experiencing sharp declines that directly impact both construction labor supply and demand for housing. Household formation among Millennials is slowing down, while Gen Z has not yet fully entered the housing market. Quarterly household growth has dropped to 1.26 million annually in early 2025, well below the 1.93 million average between 2019 and 2022 according to Harvard's Joint Center for Housing Studies. Internal migration patterns are reshaping which markets experience growth versus decline, with continued movement from high-cost coastal metros to Sun Belt and secondary cities. An aging population is shifting demand toward healthcare facilities, senior housing, and accessible design while reducing demand for traditional office and retail. These demographic headwinds create fundamental challenges for real estate investors accustomed to demand growth, requiring recalibration of long-term market assumptions and investment strategies.
problems.summary: Slowing population growth, reduced immigration, and declining household formation rates are fundamentally changing commercial real estate demand patterns across property types and markets.

barriers: Demographic trends are slow to change

rootCauses.description: Declining birth rates in developed economies
Restrictive immigration policies reducing population inflows
Housing affordability challenges delaying household formation
Remote work enabling migration to lower-cost markets

consequences.description: Reduced overall demand growth for commercial real estate
Geographic divergence with some markets growing, others declining
Shifting demand patterns by property type (more healthcare, less retail)
Construction labor shortages due to reduced immigration

problems.title: Tenant Experience and Workplace Expectations Gap in Commercial Office Properties
problems.description: Commercial office landlords face a growing gap between tenant expectations for workplace experience and what most buildings currently provide. As companies compete to attract employees back to offices, they increasingly demand amenity-rich environments including fitness centers, food and beverage options, outdoor spaces, collaborative areas, and technology-enabled services. Tenants expect seamless digital experiences for building access, room booking, service requests, and community engagement. Many buildings, particularly Class B and C properties, lack the infrastructure, capital, or operational capability to deliver these experiences. The gap creates a two-tier market: premium buildings capturing 'flight to quality' demand while commodity buildings struggle with vacancy. Landlords must balance significant capital investments in amenity upgrades against uncertain returns, particularly given hybrid work reducing overall space demand. Tenant expectations continue to evolve rapidly, creating risk that today's investments become tomorrow's obsolete features. This experience gap accelerates obsolescence for buildings unable to compete and pressures landlords to transform from space providers to hospitality-oriented service operators.
problems.summary: Office tenants increasingly expect hospitality-grade amenities and digital experiences that most buildings cannot deliver, creating a widening gap between premium and commodity properties.

rootCauses.description: Hybrid work requiring offices to 'earn' employee commute with superior experience
Talent competition driving corporate tenant expectations higher
Consumer-grade digital experiences raising baseline expectations
Traditional landlord operating models focused on space, not service

consequences.description: Flight to quality concentrating demand in premium buildings
Accelerated obsolescence for buildings unable to upgrade
Higher operating costs as landlords add services and staff
Talent retention challenges for companies in substandard buildings

existingSolutions.name: Tenant Experience Platforms
existingSolutions.description: Mobile apps integrating building access, amenity booking, and community features

sources.title: Ten Challenges Facing Commercial Real Estate in 2025
sources.relevantExcerpt: Owners and operators are finding they have to do a better job at managing assets more efficiently. Finding the 'right' building and managing it well is more critical than simply choosing the 'right sector.'

sources.title: 2026 Commercial Real Estate Outlook
sources.relevantExcerpt: The hybrid work model is here to stay. Companies are still defining their ideal work setups, which influences how much and what kind of office space they need.
